required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Thoracic Spinal Manipulation on Autonomic Nervous System
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Thoracic Spinal Manipulation on Autonomic Nervous System and Its Relation to Experimental Pain on Healthy Subjects: a Randomized, Crossover, Sham Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
This study evaluates the effect of a single high-velocity low amplitude thoracic manipulation on both autonomic nervous system activity and pressure pain threshold.
It is a crossover study, thus, each participant will undergo both interventions (thoracic spinal manipulation or a sham manipulation). The two interventions will be separated by a 48 h washout period.

detailed_description.textblock:
Several studies have shown that spinal manipulative therapies had an immediate effect on autonomic nervous system activity (sympathoexcitatory effect) and on pressure pain sensitivity (hypoalgesic effect).
Only one study assessed and found a correlation between these effects. Despite this interest, no one has assessed i) if these effects last over time and ii) if the relationship between them is reliable.
The primary aim of the study is to assess every single effect over one hour after the intervention. The secondary aim is to assess the relationship between autonomic modulation and pain modulation (if any).
Autonomic nervous system activity is assessed by measuring heart rate variability and the baroreflex sensitivity
Pain sensitivity is assessed by measuring pressure pain threshold

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline heart rate variability (HRV) at + 1 minute after treatment
primary_outcome.description: Time-domain analysis of HRV from 5 min ECG recording

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline heart rate variability (HRV) at + 15 minutes
primary_outcome.description: Time-domain analysis of HRV from 5 min ECG recording

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline heart rate variability (HRV) at 30 minutes
primary_outcome.description: Time-domain analysis of HRV from 5 min ECG recording

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline heart rate variability (HRV) at + 1 minute after treatment
primary_outcome.description: Frequency-domain analysis of HRV from 5 min ECG recording

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline heart rate variability (HRV) at + 15 minutes
primary_outcome.description: Frequency-domain analysis of HRV from 5 min ECG recording

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline heart rate variability (HRV) at 30 minutes
primary_outcome.description: Frequency-domain analysis of HRV from 5 min ECG recording

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline pressure pain threshold (PPT) at + 1 minute after treatment
primary_outcome.description: The mean of 3 successive PPT in kilopascal

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline pressure pain threshold (PPT) at + 15 minutes
primary_outcome.description: The mean of 3 successive PPT in kilopascal

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline pressure pain threshold (PPT) at 30 minutes
primary_outcome.description: The mean of 3 successive PPT in kilopascal

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Baroreflex sensitivity at + 1 minute after treatment
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and and + 1 minute after treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Continuous recording of systolic blood pressure during 5 minutes

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Baroreflex sensitivity at + 15 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Continuous recording of systolic blood pressure during 5 minutes

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline Baroreflex sensitivity at 30 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Continuous recording of systolic blood pressure during 5 minutes

intervention.description: The researcher manually applies a preload force on the T6 level followed by a single posterior to anterior thrust.
The researcher manually applies a preload force on the right scapula followed by a single lateral thrust.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First-year chiropractic student at IFEC
- Volunteer
- Healthy (no pain, no disease)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Counter indications to spinal manipulation
- Drugs intakes (pain killers or beta-blockers)
- Caffeine or tobacco intakes during the previous hour
